name: Andean Tinamou
distribution: Andes from southern Ecuador to central Chile; also in the Sierras de Córdoba, Argentina
habitat: Subtropical and tropical shrubland at elevations of 800 to 4,000 meters
diet: Omnivorous: consumes seeds, insects, and plant material
behavior: Ground-dwelling; shy and elusive; capable of short flights but prefers to run when threatened
reproduction: Males incubate eggs and care for chicks; nests are concealed on the ground
uses: Hunted locally for food; not widely used in traditional practices
description: The Andean tinamou is a ground-dwelling bird native to the Andes, characterized by its cryptic plumage and elusive behavior. It inhabits high-altitude shrublands and is known for its distinctive whistling calls.

name: Little Tinamou
distribution: Central and South America, from southern Mexico to northern South America
diet: Omnivorous: eats seeds, fruits, and small invertebrates
behavior: Secretive and elusive; prefers dense undergrowth; mostly terrestrial
reproduction: Ground-nester; males incubate eggs and care for chicks
uses: Occasionally hunted locally; not widely exploited
description: A small, shy bird that inhabits dense forests, known for its soft whistles and elusive nature.

name: Speckled Chachalaca
habitat: Tropical lowland forest and forest edges
behavior: Social and vocal; lives in small groups
reproduction: Builds nests in trees; 2–3 eggs; both parents care for young
uses: Hunted for meat in some areas
description: A noisy forest bird recognized for its spotted plumage and gregarious behavior in South American forests.

name: Andean Guan
reproduction: Tree nests, 2–3 eggs
description: Turkey-like with brown plumage and dewlap

name: Australian Brushturkey
reproduction: Mound nests, male incubates
description: Large, black, red head, yellow wattle

name: Band-tailed Guan
reproduction: Tree nests, 2–3 eggs
description: Medium-sized guan, banded tail

name: Bartlett Tinamou
reproduction: Ground nest, male incubates
description: Small, brownish, subtle markings

name: Bearded Guan
reproduction: Tree nests, 2–3 eggs
description: Guan with feathered "beard" under chin

name: Black-capped Tinamou
reproduction: Ground nest, male incubates
description: Small, black cap on head

name: Blue-throated Piping Guan
reproduction: Tree nests, 2–3 eggs
description: Glossy black, blue throat

name: Brazilian Tinamou
reproduction: Ground nest, male incubates
description: Brown plumage with streaks

name: Brown Tinamou

description: Reddish-clay underparts, chocolate-brown upperparts

name: Brushland Tinamou
distribution: Southeastern Bolivia, NW Paraguay, NW & Central Argentina

description: Grey to olive-brown barred with black, white streaks

name: Cauca Guan
distribution: Endemic to Colombia's Cauca River valley

description: Dark grey head, reddish chestnut body, bright red gular sac

name: Chaco Chachalaca

description: Brownish plumage, known for loud calls

name: Chestnut-wingedChachalaca
habitat: Subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests

description: Brownish plumage with chestnut wings

name: Cinereous Tinamou
reproduction: Ground nest, male incubates

name: Colombian Chachalaca
habitat: Subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests
reproduction: Tree nests, 2–3 eggs
description: Brownish plumage, known for loud calls

name: Crested Guan

reproduction: Tree nests, 2–3 eggs
description: Dark plumage with a distinctive crest

name: Dusky Megapode
distribution: Maluku and Raja Ampat Islands, Indonesia
reproduction: Mound nests, male incubates
description: Blackish bird with short crest, bare red facial skin

name: Dusky-legged Guan
distribution: Uruguay, NE Argentina, S Paraguay, S Brazil

description: Dark brown plumage, red dewlap

name: Dwarf Tinamou

description: Dark plumage with black, brown, and reddish-brown coloring

name: Grey Tinamou

name: Highland Tinamou
distribution: Andes of Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, Venezuela, Costa Rica, Panama

description: Mottled or barred with black and cinnamon, rufous throat

name: Little Chachalaca
distribution: Brazil, French Guiana, Suriname, Guyana, Venezuela
behavior: Forages in pairs or small flocks
reproduction: Tree nests, 3 eggs
description: Reddish chestnut head, reddish brown to gray-brown upperparts

name: Orange-footed Scrubfowl
distribution: Northern Australia, southern New Guinea, Lesser Sunda Islands
habitat: Lowland and montane rainforest, swamp forest, mangroves, arid bushy or grassy areas
reproduction: Mound nests; eggs incubated by heat from decomposing vegetation
description: Medium-sized bird with brownish olive-grey plumage, chestnut tinge on back, orange to pinkish-red legs.

name: Pale-browed Tinamou
habitat: Tropical dry forests up to 1,500 m elevation
reproduction: Ground nest; male incubates and raises chicks
description: Small tinamou with pale brow stripe; overall brownish plumage.

name: Plain Chachalaca
distribution: Southern Texas (USA) to northern Costa Rica
habitat: Brushy and thorny forests, scrubland, second-growth forest edges
reproduction: Tree nests; 2–3 eggs; both parents care for young
description: Large, chicken-like bird with gray head, olive-brown body, long tail.

name: Red-legged Tinamou
distribution: Northern South America (Colombia, Venezuela, Guyana, Suriname, Brazil)
habitat: Dry to moist deciduous forests, thorn scrub, open woodland, grasslands
reproduction: Ground nest; male incubates and raises chicks
description: Medium-sized bird with brown plumage, reddish legs, and short tail.

description: Medium-sized bird with black crown, rufous primaries, light gray to brown underparts.

reproduction: Tree nests; 2–3 eggs; both parents care for young

name: Rusty-margined Guan
habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests, including fragmented habitats
reproduction: Tree nests; 2–3 eggs; both parents care for young
